<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 675, 528]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 560, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 193, 537, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 234, 525, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 571, 294]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 304, 537, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 338, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 384, 537, 418]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 426, 625, 445]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 459, 593, 478]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 490, 527, 514]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 526, 593, 545]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 560, 625, 579]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 593, 561, 611]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 626, 581, 645]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 655, 536, 689]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 72, 544, 89]]<|/det|>
## Section A  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 102, 700, 121]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the spaces provided.

<label>1</label>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 873, 306]]<|/det|>
The Earth and the Moon may be considered to be isolated in space with their masses concentrated at their centres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 873, 337]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 245, 368]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 382, 856, 400]]<|/det|>
the angular speed of the Moon in its orbit around the Earth is \(2.66 \times 10^{- 6} \text{rad} \text{s}^{- 1}\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 567, 875, 585]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 597, 181, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

the mass of the Earth is \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 781, 875, 798]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 380, 875, 414]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Describe the main principles of the determination of the charge on an oil drop by Millikan's experiment. You may draw a diagram if you wish.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[900, 77, 937, 92]]<|/det|>
<form>For

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 89, 945, 104]]<|/det|>
Examiner's

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[900, 101, 928, 119]]<|/det|>
Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 186, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 680, 875, 714]]<|/det|>
In an experiment to determine the fundamental charge, values of charge on oil drops were found by a student to be as shown below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 725, 756, 745]]<|/det|>
\[3.2\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C};\qquad 6.4\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C};\qquad 16\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C};\qquad 9.7\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C};\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 755, 688, 775]]<|/det|>
\[12.8\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C};\qquad 3.1\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C};\qquad 6.3\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 787, 875, 821]]<|/det|>
State the value, to two significant figures, of the fundamental charge that is suggested by these values of charge on oil drops.
